feedback: I took the role of a completely egoistical manager and only considered the personal wealth without considering the consequences for the firm. Which is why I forgot to write down the firm profits and estimated them just now by cumulating the budget slack.  In retrospect, thinking about the firm income would have been smart because a failing firm couldn't pay me anything, but it's too late for that.

Mir wurde ein Budgetangebot von 5000 Talern unterbreitet und die Produktionskosten lagen bei 4000 Talern. Wenn ich jedoch nur ein Budget von 4000 Talern fordern würde, was wäre dann mit den 1000 Talern Rest passiert? Die Verwendung würde hierbei einen Unterschied in meiner Entscheidung spielen, wenn es zum einen bedeuten würde, dass die Firma nur einen geringeren Kredit aufnehmen bräuchte oder die freien Mittel dem Budget der Abteilung X zugesprochen und dort von Person Y "in die eigene Tasche" gesteckt wird.    Wieso muss das freie Budget, über den Kosten des Einkaufs, in meine Tasche fließen und kann nicht innerhalb meiner Abteilung, in Teilen zur zukünftigen Risikominimierung oder Entwicklung neuer Produkte oder Prozessstrukturen verwendet werden, um so den Unternehmenswert auf lange Sicht zu maximieren?
Ich hab mir ehrlich gesagt die Zahlen nicht gemerkt, welche sich nach der letzten Runde ergeben haben.

to statement one: i startet the first rounds wondering which compensation would help to increase both, the firm profit and my private wealth, but after like 3 rounds i realized that the highest compensation would always increase my privat wealth the most so i switched to only deciding on this fact.
how is this similar to reality?
habe mir mein wealth nicht gemerkt :(
A trial round would have Bern useful.  After the first two rounds I tried to maximize my profit while reaching a firm profit close to zero.

A fun experiment, I just hope in the “real world” that we also get compensated on how good the firm is doing, and not for “lying”. Or like Jensen said in 2003 “It encourages managers to lie and cheat, lowballing targets and inflating results, and it penalizes them for telling the truth. It turns colleague against colleague, creating distrust and ill will. And it distorts incentives, motivating people to act in ways that run counter to the best interests of their companies” (Jensen 2003, “Paying people to lie: the truth about the budgeting process”, Europe and Financial Management)    And I hope the budgets get followed up closely so that it can end up like Nicolas Hayek describes it “We are big believers in decentralization. This company has 211 profit centers. We set tough, demanding budgets for them. I personally participate in detailed budget reviews for our major profit centers. Then we track performance closely. We get monthly sales figures for all profit centers on the sixth day of the following month. We get profit and loss statements about 10 or 15 days later. The moment anything looks strange, we react very quickly, very decisively, very directly” (Nicolas Hayek, former top executive at Swatch, in: Harvard Business Review 1993)
